title: Esk Valley Walk Route

images.caption: River Esk near Sleights

images.title: Mike Kirby / Floating Drydock, Parkol Marine, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Floating Drydock, Parkol Marine with Whitby Abbey in the background

images.title: Stephen McCulloch / Bridleway approaching Hecks Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridleway approaching Hecks Wood

images.title: Peter Church / Towards Westerdale Moor and Eskdale, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Towards Westerdale Moor and Eskdale This view is north, and one of the options for the Lyke Wake Walk,  followed this route, but with the need to avoid boot erosion, and the understandable desire to visit the Lion Inn at Blakey, most walkers now continue east along the disused railway line.

images.title: Ian Petticrew, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Larpool Viaduct. Abandoned Railway Viaduct over the River Esk at Whitby

images.title: Mick Garratt / River Esk and Ruswarp Bridge
images.caption: River Esk and Ruswarp Bridge. The village of Ruswarp is on the far bank with the tower of St. Bartholomew's church prominent.

images.title: River Esk at Egton Bridge by Tom Richardson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Esk at Egton Bridge

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: St Hedda's Church, Egton Bridge. This magnificent church deserves its nickname 'Cathedral of the Moors'. St Hedda's has strong links with priest and martyr Nicholas Postgate who was born in this area and ministered to the Catholic population of this part of the moors.

description: A stunning walk through the North York Moors National Park from Castleton to Whitby . The walk begins with a loop from Castleton which passes through Danby Head, Westerdale Moor, Farndale Moor and High Blakey Moor. You return to Castleton where you begin the next section through Esk Dale to Danby and then the climb to Danby Beacon . From here it leads to Leaholm, Glaisdale , Egton Bridge and Grosmont with several sections along the River Esk. The final section takes you through Sleights to the finish point at Whitby, on the North Sea. See the Sleights to Whitby Walk for more details on this nice section. The walk passes the North York Moors Railway which you can take for part of the route. The steam railway is a significant tourist attraction and may be the busiest steam heritage line in the world, carrying around 350,000 passengers in 2009.
